data.title: Márta Sebestyén: I Can See the Gates of Heaven
data.meta_description: I Can See the Gates of Heaven is the most personal, intimate album yet from one of the most eloquent singers. Its songs are mostly traditional & Hungarian, but Márta Sebestyén's marriage of secular & sacred threads proves singular, yet universal.

MÁRTA SEBESTYÉN - 'I CAN SEE THE GATEST OF HEAVEN…'

6: 09

Bartok collected the first, secular song. The second one invokes the Virgin Mary. Márta's superb female Hungarian voice is accompanied/framed by the co-arrangers on flutes/whistles & zither/ fretless lute. Winds/reeds are played by Balázs Szokolay Dongó. Mátyás Bolya plays stringed things.

Márta says she takes Mary's Lullaby with her everywhere, 'ever since I first sang it…when I was a high school girl still wet behind the ears.' She was born in 1957.

MUSZSIKAS - 'THE BARTOK ALBUM'

Viola, violin & surging, bowed double bass play three Romanian dance melodies, slowly. Respectively, the players are Mihály Sipos, Péter Éri & Dániel Hamar. Bartók used the first melody in his second Rhapsody for Violin and Piano. He used the third one in the first of his Romanian Folk Dances.

MUZSIKAS/MARTA SEBESTEYN - 'THE PRISONER'S SONG'

4: 33

Marta Sebesyten, quite solo in the mid-1980s. A very haunting Hungarian plaint..which - a little over a decade later - suddenly reached millions of cinema-goers, worldwide, as 'that song from The English Patient.'

Its emotional potency may relate to its singer's personal circumstance when she recorded it; 'I was singing because of my own sorrow. I had to sing it that way, because I was just getting divorced from Nikola.'

JO ANN KELLY - 'DO IT & MORE'

2: 49

A stark 'he left me' blues, a cappella. Powerful, spare, absolutely solo, in 1976. Pleasingly hard to believe its singer was a white Englishwoman. Kelly died too young, in 1990. She was a capable player too. Arguably, she was the premier English blues-woman. This CD re-issues all of her 1976 LP - whence this cut comes - plus selections from her 1998 LP Open.

The song's author was a powerful-voiced ( African-Appalachian, I think ) blues-woman, of whom very little is known, biographically.

MÁRTA SEBESTYÉN - 'I CAN SEE THE GATEST OF HEAVEN…'

8: 51

Márta's glorious Hungarian female voice delivers a traditional song about the saint who was also Hungary first king ( in the 11th century ). She has sung this to Queen Elizabeth II of England. The second song is a prayer, written in the 16th century, in Croatia. Today, says Márta, 'it is preserved only in the tradition of the Hungarians in Northern Croatia.' Balázs Szokolay Dongó & Mátyás Bolya are the players; this features the former's tárogató & the latter's fretless lute.

MÁRTA SEBESTYÉN - 'I CAN SEE THE GATEST OF HEAVEN…'

6: 30

Márta's glorious Hungarian female voice sings a very haunting traditional Moldavian prayer/requiem song. At least 800 years old, it is still sung by those bidding a final farewell to a deceased, loved one. Marta recently sang it to farewell her father, in the little graveyard where his remains were placed.

Balázs Szokolay Dongó plays rim-blown flute & tárogató. Mátyás Bolya plays a wire-strung zither.
